summary: A character reference letter written by Jamie Hollomon to Judge Alison J. Nathan in support of Ghislaine Maxwell's bail request. The letter details Hollomon's long-term friendship with the Maxwell family, describes Ghislaine Maxwell's upbringing and character, and argues she is not a flight risk and intends to defend herself at trial.

persons.name: Jamie Hollomon
persons.role: Author of character reference letter, psychotherapist, family friend
persons.context: Writes a letter to Judge Alison J. Nathan in support of Ghislaine Maxwell's bail request, detailing a lifelong friendship with the Maxwell family and attesting to Ghislaine's character.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The individual for whom bail is being requested. The letter describes her upbringing, character, academic achievements, and argues she is not a flight risk and will face the charges against her.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over the case to whom the character reference letter is addressed.

persons.name: Robert Maxwell
persons.context: Described as narcissistic, controlling, demanding, and planning to leave his fortune to charity. Referred to as 'Bob' by the author.

persons.name: Betty Maxwell
persons.context: Wife of Robert Maxwell. The author provided her support after Robert's death and wrote a book expressing gratitude to her.

persons.name: Philip Maxwell
persons.context: One of Ghislaine's elder siblings with whom the author stayed in touch.

persons.name: Isabel Maxwell
persons.context: One of Ghislaine's elder siblings who cared for their mother Betty on her deathbed and with whom the author stayed in touch.

persons.name: Kevin Maxwell
persons.context: One of Ghislaine's siblings, mentioned as spending time with the author and as a subject of family reports.

connections.description: Longtime family friend who has known Ghislaine since she was young and is providing a character reference for her.

events.title: Ghislaine Maxwell remains in US
events.description: The letter states Ghislaine Maxwell made no attempt to leave the United States in 2019 despite facing civil accusations.

events.title: Death of Betty Maxwell
events.description: Betty Maxwell was on her deathbed with Parkinson's disease. Isabel Maxwell cared for her and read her a book written by Jamie Hollomon.

events.title: Robert Maxwell's death
events.description: The death of Robert Maxwell, which left his wife Betty suddenly alone.

locations: United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, New York, NY 10007
keyFacts: The document is a character reference letter submitted to the court in support of Ghislaine Maxwell's bail request in October 2020.
The author, Jamie Hollomon, claims a lifelong friendship with the Maxwell family and describes Ghislaine as mature, honest, strong-willed, and grounded in good values.

The letter argues Ghislaine Maxwell is not a flight risk, citing that she did not attempt to leave the U.S. in 2019 and has the family value of 'facing the music' instilled by her demanding father, Robert Maxwell.
Robert Maxwell is characterized as a narcissistic, controlling father who told his children he would leave his fortune to charity, forcing them to be self-reliant.
The letter reveals the Maxwell siblings (Philip, Anne, Isabel, Christine, Kevin, Ian, Ghislaine) are described as 'tight' and maintain close contact, sharing reports about each other's lives.
